Option D. Malignancy: While malignancies can cause biliary obstruction, they usually present as irregular or mass-like obstructions within the bile ducts or surrounding tissues rather than discrete, round filling defects typical of stones.

 

Treatment of CBD Stone:

 

  • Secondary CBD stones are usually stones that have slipped from the gallbladder into the CBD. Treatment typically involves ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography), which is both diagnostic and therapeutic.
  • Primary CBD stones are less common and often associated with chronic infections of the bile duct in areas of low socioeconomic status, leading to brown pigment stones due to the action of bacterial glucuronidase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Choledocholithiasis is diagnosed primarily through imaging like MRCP, which reveals stones within the common bile duct as distinct circular filling defects. This condition is a significant cause of biliary obstruction and requires prompt diagnosis and management to prevent complications such as severe biliary colic and obstructive jaundice.

questions.text: Ga-68 PSMA scan is useful for the diagnosis of which condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prostate cancer

 

Ga-68 PSMA (Gallium-68 Prostate-Specific Membrane Antigen) PET scan is a nuclear medicine imaging technique primarily used for detecting prostate cancer. PSMA is a protein expressed on the surface of prostate cancer cells, and the Ga-68 radiotracer binds specifically to this antigen, allowing for precise imaging of prostate cancer lesions. This scan is particularly useful in staging and detecting the spread of prostate cancer, making it a key tool in the management of the disease.

 

Note –

 

Gallium 68 Dotanoc – IOC for Neuroendocrine Tumor. This diagnostic test is particularly effective because it targets somatostatin receptors, which are commonly present on these tumors. While it is especially useful for identifying neuroendocrine tumors of the pancreas, Gallium 68 Dotanoc can be applied to locate other types of NETs throughout the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver cancer: Liver cancer imaging is usually done using other modalities such as CT, MRI, or PET scans with different tracers.

 

Option C. Lung cancer: Lung cancer is usually diagnosed and staged with other imaging techniques, such as CT scans, PET scans using FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose), or biopsy.

 

Option D. Colon cancer: Colon cancer diagnosis and staging rely on colonoscopy, CT scans, and sometimes FDG PET scans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ga-68 PSMA scan is specifically designed for the diagnosis and management of prostate cancer, as it targets the Prostate-Specific Membrane Antigen expressed on prostate cancer cells.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented with a history of road traffic accident. The axial CT image is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extradural Hemorrhage

 

Explanation:

 

The CT image demonstrates a right-sided hyperdense lesion, characteristic of an Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH). Features supporting this diagnosis include:

 

 

Shape and Location: The lesion exhibits a biconvex or "lens-shaped" appearance, typically not crossing sutures, localized at the pterion which is a common site for EDH due to its proximity to the middle meningeal artery (MMA).

 

Type of Trauma: Associated with high-energy trauma such as a road traffic accident, often causing arterial bleeding, specifically from the MMA.

 

Lucid Interval: Patients may experience a lucid interval where symptoms improve temporarily before deteriorating, due to the building pressure from the accumulating blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH): Typically appears as a crescentic or "banana-shaped" collection that can cross sutures but not midline. It arises from bridging veins, often due to lower-energy trauma.

 

Option C. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage: Usually presents as diffuse or patchy areas of increased density in the subarachnoid spaces, not shown in the image.

 

Option D. Intraventricular Hemorrhage: Would be visualized within the ventricular system, which is not evident here.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify this sign on USG: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Seashore sign

 

Explanation:


The image shows the "Seashore sign" on M-mode ultrasound, which is used primarily to evaluate for lung sliding. The seashore sign is characterized by a sandy or granular pattern in the lower half of the M-mode display, beneath the pleural line. This pattern is caused by the motion of the lung relative to the pleura during breathing. It is a normal finding, indicating that the lung is sliding smoothly against the parietal pleura, which helps rule out conditions like pneumothorax in the area scanned.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stratosphere sign: Also known as the "barcode sign," it appears as parallel lines in M-mode and is associated with the absence of lung sliding, often seen in cases of pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Lung point sign: This is seen in lung ultrasound as the point at which the normal seashore sign of lung sliding transitions to the stratosphere sign in cases of pneumothorax. It is specific for pneumothorax but not depicted in this ultrasound image.

 

Option D. Sinusoidal sign: Typically refers to a waveform pattern seen in various types of medical imaging and monitoring, not relevant to the depiction of lung sliding on ultrasound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lung sliding- seen at the pleural lining due to relative motion between pleural layer. Seashore sign- M mode counterpart of lung sliding. Motion of the lung deep to the pleura causes grainy appearance in M-mode, stimulating sand in a seashore.
